content: I'm considering to build a contrib sub-theme of Basis, holding not more than (1) the .info file, (2) an empty skin-custom.css, and (3) a README file. This would make sub-theming a lot easier, in my opinion.

Now, I'm looking for a good theme name which reflects the relation of Basis as the base theme and the sub-theme. I'm sort of struggling with the term sub (which probably represents the concept of inheritance) because using a sub-theme, you build on top of a base theme.
I'm interested in feedback which concept should be represented in the theme name: (a) being a sub-theme, or (b) being something which builds on top of the base theme?

I think that depends on who it is you believe the target audience is. If you think it is people who are familiar with theming in Drupal, then (a). Otherwise, (b) might be better. Or you could go with (c), and ignore what the name should represent, but clearly document what it is for at the very top of the README file. :slight_smile:

Probably not only people who are familiar with theming in Drupal, so (b) might be better. Here some first ideas:

  • Basis => Cover
  • Basis => Skin (problem, there's a skin.css in Basis)
  • Basis => Topping

Other ideas? What do you (all) think? Also interested in feedback because I'm not a native English speaker.

Or you could go with (c), and ignore what the name should represent ...

Sure, that will be my fallback strategy!
Rather than think about it in terms of either sub or on top, what about extend (which I think would address both ideas in one), and coming up with a name that represents that?
Extending the theme, yes, sounds interesting! Do you have a term in mind (not the perfect one, just as an example)?
I keep meaning to make a drush command to do this, but then i don't; ... carry on;
@Geoff St. Pierre (serundeputy) To make sub-themes, or to come up with names? :wink::big_smile:
Sorry, Olaf, I do not have anything that comes to mind.
I like cover as a name ... cover all your bases :slight_smile: in the README.md you can say cover extends the basis theme;
Duvet?
"All you Basis are belong to us"?
Duvet sounds nice, didn't know the term.
Is it common, or kind of exotic?
"Duvet" is common in English I believe ...but it must derive from French ...at least it sound like it.

I was thinking that "Basic" is a good candidate based on your description @Olaf Grabienski ...but it seems that this namespace is take in d.org: https://www.drupal.org/project/structure
...I have a habit of looking up the definition/etymology of words, and their origin (I'm a Google/Wikipedia freak :sweat_smile: ) ...also like looking up synonyms etc. Perhaps these will give you an idea.
So, I like these various definitions of "base", which originates from the Greek word "basis":

the lowest part or edge of something, especially the part on which it rests or is supported.
the underlying support or foundation for an idea, argument, or process
the part of a column between the shaft and pedestal or pavement. (in architecture)
So you could have the Basis, and then a "Pillar" built on top of it.
...pillar is not taken in d.org: https://www.drupal.org/project/pillar
Duvet, in Canada at least, means a specific kind of bed covering
That's what it means in OZ as well.
I was right; it is French:
Screen-Shot-2020-05-13-at-7.05.23-pm.png

pillar is not taken in d.org

cover and duvet are also available
:+1:
I hope this helps come up with a name:
image.png
Thanks @klonos, interesting! I guess however, pillar is too specific.
Sounds like what is placed on top of a "base" is called a "shaft"
Not taken: https://www.drupal.org/project/shaft
There are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things.

...or:

There are 2 hard problems in computer science: cache invalidation, naming things, and off-by-1 errors.
That's the one.
There are 5 hard problems in computer science: cache invalidation, naming things, off-by-1 errors, and people who cannot count.
Thanks for all your input so far!
Sometimes people go for what we call double-barrelled family names, e.g. Smith-Jones. Perhaps you could do this with Basis and your subtheme could be Olaf-Basis, or similar.

double-barrelled family names ...

Nice idea: Sub-Basis, Basis-Sub, Basis-Cover ... Or wait, I also like Smith-Jones :slight_smile:
thesis?
ie. the basis of your argument is developed into a thesis
ReBasis
proof
qed
basis-starter the sour dough of themes.
Thesis is brilliant, also because of the ending! Will people expect too much of it?
I mean, basically it will be an empty theme.
Though, depends on the README ... that could become quite elaborated.
:writing: and the wiki, I suppose

@Olaf Grabienski It sounds to me like what you're proposing is "Basis Unloaded." :-)

But I'd suggest (as a resident newbie to Backdrop), don't do anything too clever. As a new guy, I went shopping for themes and ended up subtheming Basis myself because it had the best documentationâ€”which is to say, I frequently got lost quickly looking at the others. You can help people like me by naming it "Basis NoCSS," which makes it very clear how it differs as a base theme from regular Basis (also considered a base theme, yes?).

Thanks for your feedback, @Jeff Porten ! I'd say the theme would differ from regular Basis as it provides the space to extend Basis. In this respect, I see Basis as a base theme (and also because I find it very suitable as a starting point, together with the core layouts including Bootstrap 4 classes). However, in contrast to other base themes, Basis is even usable without any changes, in this respect I wouldn't call it 'only' a base theme.

Regarding the name: "Basis NoCSS" would reflect the starting point quite good (even if other aspects like JavaScript or template files aren't covered) but once people add their own CSS, the name might be misleading.

However, the discussion is very inspiring! E.g., at the beginning, I didn't consider to choose a composed name which contains "Basis" like "Basis Starter", but it might help to get the idea at first sight. However, personally I like figurative names like "Thesis" or "Cover". I guess I'll think again about it!
Hey, I've made an initial release of ... tadaaaa: Thesis! Here it is: https://backdropcms.org/project/thesis
So the question is now, to use Thesis, do you hack it, or subtheme it? :slight_smile:
I'd say, hack it. If you want to subtheme, Basis should be the base theme, not Thesis.
Which raises the question of Thesis updates. There won't be many, apart of the README.
That's also the reason for not having more directories, like templates. Would make updating difficult, when people hack Thesis, add own templates etc.

Well, actually updating will however be a mess. Not sure if clear update notes will help. Who reads them? So, Thesis may be good for starters, but it's for sure limited. Here are the current alternatives that I know of: https://github.com/backdrop-contrib/thesis#alternatives-to-thesis

backdrop-contrib/thesis
Thesis extends Basis, the default theme in Backdrop. - backdrop-contrib/thesis

Olaf Grabienski said:

Hm, usually there are submenus. Have you checked the menu settings via the Layout / Block UI?

In Basis, the primary navigation menu is usually below the header. I moved it to the header and the header menu is not set up to have dropdowns. I will need to change that.

Found a better way to do it. Rather than use the menu in header block. I moved the position of the primary navigation block next to the header for this theme, instead of below it, via css. That way it captures all the dropdown functionality I need without the extra coding. Much simpler. DUH!

Elisabeth Garbeil said:

Just some info for anyone else that does this - it does require some theming this way to customize (changing breakpoints, etc.), but a heck of a lot less than adding dropdown capability to another menu. Although that may be something I need to do in the future, just not this site.
